stem: Dr. {{candidate_name}}, you are about to anaesthetise a 45-year-old man for elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy. He has a BMI of 38, Mallampati grade 3, and limited neck extension. How would you approach this airway?

expectedKeyFacts: History: previous anaesthetics, difficult intubation, OSA symptoms, reflux
Examination: Mallampati score, thyromental distance, neck extension, mouth opening
Look for: obesity, short neck, receding mandible, prominent teeth, beard
Risk stratification: predict difficult mask ventilation and difficult intubation
STOP-BANG score for OSA screening
Plan A, B, C, D — DAS difficult airway guidelines
Equipment check: ensure rescue devices available

prompts.text: You induce anaesthesia and cannot intubate. Mask ventilation is just adequate. What is your immediate plan?
expectedKeyFacts: DAS Plan B: maintain oxygenation with face mask ventilation
Call for help
Optimize head position, two-person technique, adjuncts (Guedel, NPA)
Second-generation supraglottic airway (i-gel, LMA Supreme)
Limit attempts: maximum 3 intubation attempts
Consider: wake the patient if adequate ventilation and elective surgery
Avoid repeated laryngoscopy causing trauma and oedema
Maintain anaesthesia and oxygenation

prompts.text: You insert an i-gel and ventilation improves. What are your options now?
expectedKeyFacts: Proceed with surgery via supraglottic airway if suitable (short, low aspiration risk)
Attempt fibreoptic intubation through the i-gel using Aintree catheter
Wake the patient and consider awake fibreoptic intubation
In this case: laparoscopy contraindicated with SGA — high aspiration risk
Best option: wake patient, explain, plan awake FOI or postpone
Document clearly in notes and alert patient
Do NOT make repeated attempts at direct laryngoscopy

prompts.text: If you could not ventilate via face mask or i-gel, what would you do?
expectedKeyFacts: Can't intubate, can't oxygenate (CICO) — emergency
Declare emergency, call for help
Final attempt: optimise head position, two-person BMV, consider LMA
Front of neck access: scalpel cricothyroidotomy
DAS CICO guidelines: identify cricothyroid membrane
Technique: transverse stab incision, rotate scalpel 90°, bougie, railroaded tube
Do NOT delay — hypoxic brain injury after 3-4 minutes
Equipment: scalpel (size 10 blade), bougie, size 6.0 cuffed ETT

rescuePrompt: Perhaps you could talk me through the DAS difficult airway algorithm — what are the key plans A, B, C, and D?
keyFacts: Pre-operative airway assessment: history and examination
Mallampati, thyromental distance, neck extension, mouth opening
Plan A: facemask ventilation and tracheal intubation
Plan B: maintaining oxygenation — supraglottic airway
Plan D: emergency front of neck access
Wake the patient if elective and adequate oxygenation

scoringGuidance.pass: Systematic airway assessment, recognises predictors of difficulty, follows DAS algorithm structure, appropriate escalation through plans, identifies CICO and scalpel cricothyroidotomy, considers waking patient; stronger candidates discuss fibreoptic options and risk-benefit of proceeding with SGA
scoringGuidance.borderline: Mentions some assessment features but unsystematic, aware of DAS guidelines but unclear on specific plans, mentions cricothyroidotomy but technique vague
scoringGuidance.fail: No structured assessment, does not follow DAS algorithm, makes repeated intubation attempts, delays emergency front of neck access, unaware of CICO definition
